title.rendered: Where You Going, Where You From

content.rendered:
E Street Shuffle will cease publication on January 5, 2026.

I tend to bury the lede at times, so I figured I’d better start with that.

Since it’s been more than a year since I’ve written any new essays, this is admittedly more de facto than decision. Still, I thought I should acknowledge it rather than have the site simply vanish one day without explanation.

Also, I know that there are some (including the kind folks at E Street Radio, to whom I am grateful for the years of daily acknowledgement) who rely on this site for research, so I wanted to give an advance heads up.

I’d like to thank everyone who’s visited, subscribed, commented, encouraged, guest authored, corrected my mistakes and copious typos, and invited me to participate in the community of content producers in the Springsteen fandom community. I learned a lot, and I am deeply appreciative.

All things end, though, and soon this site will too.

Here’s what the months ahead look like:

Already in effect: All commenting has been disabled site-wide for version control as I work on archiving the site. I did this a few days ago, and I apologize for not acknowledging it sooner.

Now through January 5, 2026: Kingdom of Days will continue its daily publication schedule. The last post will be on January 5th, which marks the official end of the series’ eighth year. That seemed like a nice place to tie the bow..

Concurrently, I’ll be reviewing every Roll of the Dice, Cover Me, Meeting Across the River, and other posts I’ve published over the last eight years in preparation for archiving. I’ll repair or replace any broken links or media, update live performance statistics, etc. so the articles are as clean as possible. For previously unreleased tracks that are now available on Tracks II: The Lost Albums, I will note the additional release in the article footer but will not revisit the main text other than to correct factual statements in light of the official release. I expect this work to be completed by December 31st.

January 6, 2026: This site essentially becomes a zombie, while I make a personal, offline archive of the site. I will also delete the entire subscriber database on this date so there’s no retention of your email address (if you are a subscriber).

What happens after that is still a little fuzzy. At some point in 2026, this site will completely vanish, but  I don’t know exactly when that will happen. When I started this site, I went through a gradual process of licensing the software, web hosting, domain names, plugins, backup service, media hosting, etc., and I don’t remember when those all come up for annual renewal.

I’m basically just going to let everything expire organically, and whatever link in the chain breaks first will likely be what takes the site down. I started seriously considering creating a blog toward the end of 2017, so I’m guessing the blog will be a decaying zombie for most of next year. Regardless, I won’t be monitoring or maintaining it. (Zombies are gross.)

But of course we’ll always have Paris, thanks to the Wayback Machine.

So that’s that.

I’ll send another update/reminder as the end approaches, but for now:

Thanks again for reading, today and for as much of the last eight years as you’ve been with me.

excerpt.rendered: It’s a long goodbye, but the end of this blog is coming.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Introduction
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: We're two years old! Thanks for joining--I hope you stick around for year three!

jetpack-related-posts.title: ROTD/MatR/Cover Me, Gary U.S. Bonds, Bruce Springsteen & The E Street Band, This Little Girl
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Bruce penned "This Little Girl" for Gary U.S. Bonds' comeback album, and it worked--providing Bonds with a Top 40 (and almost a Top 10) hit, powered by the E Street Band and Bruce's lyrics, music, and backing vocals.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Where the Band Was: Oakland, October 26, 2007
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Oakland '07 was a solid early-tour outing with a fantastic main set (if a lackluster encore)--and it was my last show with Danny Federici.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Where the Band Was: Milan, November 28, 2007
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: My first show in Milano hooked me on Italian shows forever--once I managed to survive getting inside.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Roll of the Dice: Out in the Street
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: A departure at the time, "Out in the Street" established a theme of community in Bruce's songwriting that became a hallmark of the E Street Band experience.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Cover Me: It’s All Over Now, Baby Blue
jetpack-related-posts.author: Ken
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Stop what you're doing and listen. The Bruce Springsteen Band's cover of Bob Dylan's "It's All Over Now, Baby Blue" is one of their finest pre-E Street moments.
